title: Thursday, 10th November, 2016
bodyHTML:

PM

11:04 am

For when the wheels came off over here

PM

And now a wheels come off

PM

Dark times

11:05 am
BE

We've been having an interesting conversation offline about the odd shift in narrative over the past 24 hours.

BE

As in, the consensus -- not just in the financial community but beyond it too -- is heading towards, "actually this is all fine".

It's not fine

PM

11:06 am

Well, it's a reflection of hope being the thing with feathers, and all that schtick. But there's a theme that a a Trump presidency is best approached with some kind of pragmatism.

(head_like_a_rock -- bye)

The pragmatism the man himself is incapable of showing.

11:07 am
BE

One can see it in the markets, of course. Dow soaring overnight. FTSE up 1% early.

BE

I'm thinking that, because Trump's message has been incoherent, the US is now a blank space onto which you can project whatever you fancy.

Stocks are up cos there's nowhere for the money to go

11:08 am

PM

UK?

PM

Nope

11:08 am

Germany? Nope

PM

BE

That's not true. Let's be fair here. We all predicted the usual panic trades -- gold etc -- and we were wrong.

11:09 am

BE

It's chosen to look kinda cautiously on the Nafta withdrawal stuff, but it might all work out right?

BE

It's chosen to take on face value the tax cuts and simplifying government stuff.

11:09 am
BE

It's chosen to just ignore the infantile protectionism and the "direct the Secretary of the Treasury to label China a currency manipulator" stuff.

BE

It's chosen to not even mention the hateful vilification of immigrants stuff ...

BE

..... Because it's quite difficult to build into asset class valuations the risk of the world's biggest economy lurching into proto-totalitarianism.

11:10 am
PM

Hmmm, I'm really not sure Bryce. I think this is all down to QE

PM

It's all down to the smoothing operation post Crunch

BE

Money's dumb because there's a lot of it? I don't entirely buy that theory.

11:11 am
PM

Well, we'll have to disagree

PM

Trump's a clown. It's not a pragmatic reaction from the markets. It's cos there;s nowhere for the money to flow

PM

Markets no longer acknowledge political risk

11:12 am
PM

It's bizzare

PM

PM

But yeah, I'll shut up

11:13 am

Well, I guess I'm more optimistic than you. I'm more optimistic in human nature's potential for delusional happiness rather than reactive depression.

PM

The world has truly turned upside down when you can state: I guess I'm more optimistic than you

11:14 am
BE

And with that, we should perhaps move on. There's enough of this elsewhere.

undefined

11:16 am

PM

(not so dumb, i guess)

BE

Okay then, let's do this. Here's a wodge of grey to talk about why the US president putting out a post-election manifesto that calls China a "currency manipulator" is positive for Chinese metals demand.

11:18 am
BE

Barclays incoming.

BE

We see a number of positive thematics coming through from this. We would expect if anything an increased fiscal response from China. Trump, in his election speech, was talking infrastructure spend very early on and fiscal stimulus is a policy expectation. This may lead to inflation fears (as do other aspects of an anti-trade world), delivering in turn an increased appetite for physical assets. And finally the sector on current commodity prices is one of the cheapest in the market, we believe. Offsetting that will be the pressure put on Chinese exports and that the current spend by China is unsustainable. Overall, we still believe the sector is set fair for the next six months.

BE

China fiscal stimulus more likely to continue augmented by the US?

The view from our Chinese economist post the recent change in Finance Minister was that fiscal stimulus might, if anything increase – see (China: Departure of Finance Minister Lou). We suspect that, as was the case post Brexit, China will be prepared to keep going, if not increase, with the current FAI focused economic policy. We can’t help think that Chinese steel demand projections are set to rise from the current flat to down which could create expectations of a deficit all of a sudden in a capital constrained iron ore world.

Trump’s fiscal intentions are still to be made clear but as our macro economists pointed out in their conference call today the fact that his victory was reasonably emphatic (despite losing the popular vote) and accompanied a greater than expected swing for the Republicans suggest implementation maybe easier. We note that Trump spoke of infrastructure spend in his acceptance speech.

11:18 am
BE

Heightened concern over inflation likely to lead to a hunt for physical assets

This can affect all commodities given their “financialisation” but traditionally this tends to benefit precious metals and then the more liquid screen traded industrial metals. To our mind it’s really too early to be talking to this sort of effect but the shift in perception has been clearly enough today for instance.

It comes at a time though when most commodities prices are facing some supply constraints. Coal is the most obvious but the recent change to Grasberg copper production profile has, for instance, created a deficit in the Woodmac supply and demand model for next year, albeit a small one. Zinc and nickel also face supply issues in one form or another. Iron ore not so much but that is mainly because steel demand projections for next year are very restrained. We would also point out that a coking coal price of $310/t is not commensurate with iron ore at $70/t, so we see no reason why the reason price momentum in the latter cannot continue in the short term.

Antofagasta PLC (ANTO:LSE): Last: 731.00, up 89.5 (+13.95%), High: 739.50, Low: 662.00, Volume: 3.22m
Glencore PLC (GLEN:LSE): Last: 287.65, up 17.4 (+6.44%), High: 290.00, Low: 277.00, Volume: 47.62m
11:19 am
Vedanta Resources PLC (VED:LSE): Last: 892.00, up 111 (+14.21%), High: 898.50, Low: 791.50, Volume: 661.97k
Anglo American PLC (AAL:LSE): Last: 1,261, up 67.5 (+5.66%), High: 1,271, Low: 1,216, Volume: 4.73m
BE

Any number of upgrades of Glencore around.

11:20 am
BE

Credit Suisse, for instance.

BE

We raise our target price from £2.5 to £3.0 and reiterate our
OUTPERFORM rating: The result of the US election increases the level of
uncertainty around global economic policy and currencies, but, as long as
global growth is not derailed, the earnings trends and valuations for the
mining sector remain compelling. For Glencore, deleveraging targets have
been met, a dividend restart is imminent and the recovery in cash flows is yet
to be fully priced in by the market. We understand investors' nervousness
around high coal prices, but even under our conservative base case
estimates the company should generate FCF in 2017 of greater than $4.3bn/10% yield
(~$7bn/16% at spot prices) and the underpin from marketing (~$2bn FCF)
gives the group added cash flow stability vs peers.

BE

Coal outlook: The Chinese authorities have engineered a supply squeeze
aimed at reducing excess supply and improving coal industry profitability.
Thermal and coking coal prices have more than doubled in 2016 and we
expect rising supply to lead prices lower in 2017. However, our estimates of
the government targeted price level of $60-75/t is materially above
consensus and the level priced into the shares ($55-60/t).

11:20 am
BE

2017 outlook: At the Investor Update on 1 Dec we expect volume, capex
and cost guidance for 2017 and potentially details on the future dividend
policy (we assume a 40% payout of FCFs from 2017). For zinc we now
assume only 100-150 kt of suspended volumes return (positive for zinc
prices) and we assume group capex of ~$3.8bn (2016 ~ $3.5bn).

BE

Valuation: We raise 2017 EBITDA by 6% to $10.4bn (spot ~$14bn) to reflect
MTM coal prices for Q4/Q1 and higher annual contract coal prices in 2017.
Our estimates are on an attributable basis and reflect all of the announced
divestments and the 55 mt coal hedge disclosed in August. Our Target Price
is based on 6x industrial EV/EBITDA and 12x marketing PE.

BE

... and HSBC, with a slightly dull initiation note that puts a 300p on Glen.

11:22 am
PM

hehehe

BE

We've also got the coal trade, as summarised by Jefferies .........

BE

While the recent spike in coal prices may be unsustainable, we think consensus
forecasts are far too low (especially for coking coal). Higher than expected coal
prices should lead to higher than expected prices for other commodities. We
have increased our coal, aluminum, copper, zinc and iron ore price forecasts,
upgraded GLEN, S32, and CNXC from Hold to Buy, and upgraded AAL and VED
from Underperform to Hold. BHP, GLEN and S32 are our top picks.

11:22 am
BE

Coal price inflation is spreading: Global coal price strength can be attributed to
Chinese coal supply restrictions and transportation problems, supply disruptions elsewhere,
and some speculation. Seaborne thermal coal prices have more than doubled and coking
coal prices have quadrupled. Domestic Chinese thermal coal supply restrictions are being
partially lifted, and a supply response in China and elsewhere is coming. However, prices
are likely to remain high (thermal coal in China to stay above 550 RMB/t versus spot at
708 RMB/t and the 1H16 avg. of 373 RMB/t). In addition, tightness in coal markets should
lead to higher prices for other commodities (steel, aluminum, iron ore, zinc, chrome). Our
analysis indicates that this is happening already and is underappreciated by the market.
We have increased our commodity price forecasts and earnings estimates (Exhibits 21-23)
to reflect this coal-driven commodity price inflation. Based on our new NPV estimates, we
have upgraded Glencore, S32 and CNXC from Hold to Buy and we have upgraded Anglo
American and Vedanta from Underperform to Hold.

BE

Cash flow and capital returns: On our new estimates, FCF yields in mining are
extraordinarily high (Exhibit 4), even at commodity prices well below current spot. We
expect strong dividend growth for BHP, Rio and South32 in 2017 (forecasted yields of
5.8%, 4.8%, and 4.9%, respectively). Glencore and Anglo are likely to reinstate dividends
in February as their balance sheets have improved and their FCF is strong. Capital returns
as well as consensus earnings upgrades should be positive for mining shares in 2017. BHP,
GLEN and S32 are our top picks. Over a longer-term horizon, our analysis indicates that FCX
and FM have the greatest upside potential. However, the big move higher in copper is still
unlikely before 2018 despite recent fundamental improvements.

BE

We believe Mr. Trump’s election win brings
material multi-year upside potential to the European defence sector. (1) Mr
Trump has pledged to increase US defence spending. (2) He has pledged to
stop “subsidizing” NATO, which could drive a material defence spending
increase for non-US NATO members. (3) He wants other US allies like Japan
to spend more on defence, rather than rely on the US for security. (4) Defence
stocks are an attractive safe haven in a world of weak GDP growth and
growing geo-political uncertainty.

BE

And UBS .....

11:31 am
BE

DoD's base budget is currently capped by the bipartisan budget agreement (for FY17)
and sequestration thereafter (Budget Control Act), which remains the law of the land.
We believe a Republican sweep increases the likelihood that sequestration is undone,
more so without corresponding equal increase for non-defense discretionary spending
that Democrats have previously demanded. Both Trump and Republican party
platforms list overturning sequestration as a priority.

BE

We estimate a return to pre-sequestration DoD budget would imply a level similar to
the FY12 proposal (Gates budget) at ~$560B with 2.5% CAGR to ~$615B (Figure 1).
This is generally 5% higher than current plan including FY17 request at ~$530B. Initial
FY18 budget request due in February, although new administrations are traditionally a
few months late with their submission.

BE

DoD is currently operating under a continuing resolution (CR), which maintains funding
at prior year levels. CR expires 12/9, providing one month to pass a FY17 funding bill or
extend CR. Key debate is how much funding within the OCO (supplemental) account is
directed towards base budget needs beyond the $5B that was in the initial budget
request. Press reports (InsideDefense) also indicate that the administration is likely to
submit a small additional OCO (war spending) request ($3-6B)

11:38 am
PM

We think it will be of little surprise that many of the largest international cash balances are held by the technology titans, representing seven of the ten largest corporate cash piles. Indeed, at the end of 2015 Apple, Microsoft, Alphabet, Cisco, Oracle, Intel and Qualcomm had a combined c.$565B in cash and cash equivalents. While the release of these large trapped cash balances would be a positive in theory and considered a tailwind for the sector such as returning cash to shareholders, investments for growth, M&A, the advantage is unlikely to be as great as assumed in our view.

PM

Trump speaks like a Keynesian. He is pro spending (tax cuts/fiscal stimulus). A new-'New Deal'. On that basis fiscal stimulus should go up. Wage growth in the US is now rising at the fastest pace since recovery began, +2.8% YoY. Unemployment is low and Trump wants to create more American jobs. Trump's victory says something about inequality and globalisation. Large parts of America have been displaced by outsourcing and cheaper labour. If these things reverse, labour costs could increase and the ratio of labour/GDP - which in 2012 amounted to c.43% of GDP, the lowest since 1929 (NYT) - could go up. Labour may regain share vs Capital. Bad news for corporate margins, especially big employers with thin margins and little pricing power.

BE

"Trump speaks like a Keynesian" is perhaps the most charitable interpretation I've read so far.

A Pfizer exit from the consumer health business, which includes lip balm Chapstick and painkiller Advil, would be one of its biggest corporate moves since abandoning a $160 billion deal to buy Irish drugmaker Allergan Inc earlier this year.

BE

BE

he results reflect a good performance from National Grid although the shares look slightly more expensive than most of its European network utilities peers, in our view. Hold.

11:49 am
BE

H1 results
The company reported H1 EBIT of £1851m (DB estimate £1736m, consensus
£1802m, last year £1836m); adjusted EPS of 28.2p (DB 25.7p, consensus
26.9p, last year 28.2p) and DPS of 15.17p (DB estimate 15.4p, last year 15.0p).
The better results partly reflected timing differences, with National Grid also
benefiting from the weaker GBPUSD exchange rate. DPS was slightly lower
than our estimate although the company reiterated its policy to grow its DPS in
line with RPI inflation, with the final DPS making up any difference with FY
inflation. Net debt was higher than expected at £29,222m (DB estimate
£27,175m, last year £24,592m).

BE

FY guidance
National Grid reiterated key aspects of its guidance for FY 2015/16. It said that
it expected UK operating profit broadly in-line with last year, in spite of the
higher H1 profits. It confirmed its aim for a return on regulatory equity of
around 8% in the US, similar to last year, although highlighted the potential for
some benefit from the new rate cases in Massachusetts and New York. It
reiterated that it expects profits from other activities to drop to more normal
levels. While its H1 net debt was higher than our estimate, it said it expected it
to remain around this level for the FY, which is in line with our FY estimate.

BE

National Grid versus its network utility peers
National Grid is performing very well under its UK price controls and recent US
price reviews suggest progress in improving its US returns. However, we think
that its shares are slightly more expensive than its European network utility
peers. It has a 2017E regulatory earnings yield (dividend yield plus equity RAB
growth) of c.6.1%. This is below the range of c.7-8% for other European
networks, although higher than the average regulatory earnings yield for
mostly regulated US energy utilities of under 6%.

11:49 am
BE

And RBC.

BE

Half year results are increasingly less meaningful for NG as the company now only provides
updates on regulatory returns on a full year basis. However the numbers reported this morning can be categorised as reassuring. The next key event is the potential sale of the majority stake in the gas distribution activities – we continue to value these assets at £12.4bn versus most reported price tags of £10-11bn. Over the medium term the NG share price is likely to be driven by events in the US. On the one hand greater fiscal stimulus and infrastructure investment under Donald Trump should be supportive, but if this leads to a steeper trajectory in rate hikes this could be a negative. For now we remain on the sidelines at Sector Perform but keeping a watching brief with a valuation gap opening up between the current share price (1005p/sh) and our price target (1080p/sh).

BE

And that's enough of that, I feel.

BE

Here's Investec to talk us though what' gone wrong this time.

BE

H1 results were disappointing with FY guidance lowered again on poor
performance in the UAE and weaker margin in South Africa. Group revenues
rose 27% to £1283m, of which 16pp came from the acquisition of Al Noor and
8pp from FX. Underlying EBITDA rose 11% (5% ex FX) to £330m, but underlying
EPS fell 26% to 12.8p reflecting new shares issued for the acquisition. Our
estimates are placed under review until further detail is available, but we
anticipate consensus downgrades of c.2% to FY17 sales and c.4% to EBITDA.

11:55 am
BE

UAE problems continue: In the UAE, as already stated in the trading update
on 9 September, the business has been impacted by reimbursement changes
in Abu Dhabi, a large number of doctor vacancies and delayed opening of new
facilities. Proforma bed days rose 3.1% but there was a mix shift to lower
margin patients, with Thiqa outpatients as a percentage of the total falling from
21.6% to 14.7% and Thiqa inpatients falling from 19.9% to 12.3%. The
company now expects a further AED150m impact to FY revenues, leading to an
overall decline versus prior year proforma (AED3392m). EBITDA margin is now
expected to be at the bottom end of previous guidance (mid-high teens).

BE

FY17 consensus downgrades expected: The new UAE guidance implies c. 6%
downgrades to UAE revenues and 17% to EBITDA, this translates to group
downgrades of c.2% to revenues and 4% to EBITDA. We believe investors will be
disappointed by the company’s apparent difficulty in setting guidance and expect
the shares to be weak today.

PM

5 Reasons to buy Real Assets
1. Buy Humiliation, Sell Hubris: price relative of real assets (real estate, commodities,
collectibles) to financial assets (stocks & bonds) at its lowest level since 1926; US
stocks close to all-time highs versus US house prices; US bonds at all-time highs
versus diamonds (Chart 1); 10-year rolling return from commodities lowest since
1933.
2. Peak Deflation: real assets positively correlated with inflation; stocks & bonds
negatively correlated with inflation; central banks are withdrawing stimulus as
deflation fears subside; real assets hedge against inflation & monetary tightening;
real asset relative performance has 82% correlation to Fed funds rate since 1950.
3. War on Inequality: commodities, real estate & infrastructure are natural
beneficiaries of a “War on Inequality” waged via fiscal stimulus.
4. Cheap Value: real estate (REITs 3.3%, timber 2.6%, agriculture 2.6%) &
infrastructure (3.2%) are higher yielding assets than global stocks & bonds.
5. Positioning: Asset allocation to real assets is low but on the rise (just 8.2% of total
ETF market cap is exposed to real assets; pension fund up from 9% to 24% past 15
years).

PM

Lefevre -- if you want a copy, mail me

11:57 am
PM

The Thundering Word: Peak Liquidity + Peak Globalization + Peak Inequality = Big Rotation

• Peak Liquidity + Peak Globalization + Peak Inequality = Peak Returns and Big Rotation

• 2016: Buy what central banks buy. 2017: Buy what fiscal stimulates. 2016 & 2017: Buy what nobody else owns

• Fed hike trades: long banks/short govt bonds, long Italian equities/short gold, long EU banks/short US utilities/REITs

12:01 pm
Ophir Energy PLC (OPHR:LSE): Last: 80.00, up 11 (+15.94%), High: 80.25, Low: 71.50, Volume: 3.11m
BE

Here's Davy with the detail.

BE

Ophir has announced that it is forming a Joint Operating
Company (JOC) with OneLNG to finance and develop the
Fortuna Floating LNG (FLNG) project offshore Equatorial
Guinea. There are valuation implications as the transaction will
leave Ophir with a smaller share of what now looks to be a
smaller than originally envisaged FLNG project. However, the
creation of the JOC provides a path to monetising a key project
in Ophir’s portfolio while containing its impact on the group’s
balance sheet.

PM

(chad_john -- yes it is. It's stupidly bad.)

BE

And RBC, fresh off the conference call.

BE

The market has reacted positively to today’s news that Ophir is establishing a Joint Operating Company with midstream partner OneLNG, a JV between
Schlumberger and Golar LNG; the stock was marked 12% higher (77p) at the end of the conference call (at 09.30).
Significant additional work is required to assess the deal/new project; but we would simplify the update by saying that Ophir has exchanged an 80% stake in an
uncertain upstream opportunity for a 33.4% stake in a integrated gas project that appears to be progressing. Based upon our $60/bbl long-term real
assumptions, yesterday’s 69p share price included only ~10p/share for Block R - our 98p/share Tangible NAV comprises of a 59p/share Core NAV plus a
risked 39p/share for Block R.

12:02 pm
BE

Key milestones:
1. Finalisation of debt arrangement: management says the JOC has been offered attractive terms to borrow $1.2bn; given lower capex management
envisages rapid payback.
2. Gas off-take contract: discussions have progressed with four credible buyers and a Brent-index gas sales contract could be announced shortly.
3. Construction contracts: the project is expected to cost $2bn to achieve first gas in H1/20, and most costs have been nailed down already. Ophir expects
to limit its cash exposure to first gas to $150m.
4. Shareholder approval: it is a sizeable deal, Ophir is effectively swapping 53% of its 80% interest in Block R for a 33.8% stake in a midstream project (on
completion of the deal OPHR would own 27% of Block R and 33.8% of the midstream facility, the government has a 20% stake in Block R).
5. Government approval: the participants have kept the government abreast of ongoing developments.

The market is cool on gas/LNG and relatively nervous about FLNG; a Brent-indexed gas sales contract should help address the former and time should help
address the latter. Having surged today, we expect the stock to pause for breath before responding positively to the achievement of key milestones.
